data.title: Our Team
data.text:
Frank Fernandez joined the Community Foundation for Greater Atlanta in August 2020, where he leads one of America’s top 20 largest community foundations. The united power of his prior experience and the anchor institution’s 70 plus years of regional leadership combine as a force for good, championing equity and shared prosperity for all who call the Atlanta region home.

Frank builds upon the Foundation’s exceptional resources, leveraging a full range of assets – human, reputational and financial – to pursue equity of opportunity through servant leadership, sustainable change making in both systems and place-based work as well as through inspired giving that ultimately fulfills the Foundation’s mission to lead our region toward equity and shared prosperity for all. To that end, during the pandemic and in partnership with the United Way of Greater Atlanta, he led programming to raise and deploy $30M in grants to the nonprofit front lines.

Prior to joining the Foundation, he served for six years as the Senior Vice President for The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation, where he led transformational revitalization of Atlanta’s Westside while simultaneously directing Blank’s community development, global giving, health access and social justice initiatives.

A recognized leader on affordable housing, transportation and economic development, Fernandez’ 15 years in management positions in Texas prior to joining the Blank Foundation included eight years leading Green Doors, an Austin nonprofit devoted to transforming lives and neighborhoods and five years as Deputy Director of PeopleFund, a community development financial institution. His work has been honored with the 2005 Austin Livable City Vision Award, the 2008 Austin Under 40 Nonprofit Leadership Award and the 2012 Ernst and Young Social Entrepreneur of the Year Award. He currently serves as a member of the Mission Investors Exchange Board of Directors. Frank is an ADL and The Aspen Institute Civil Society Fellow.

A son of Cuban immigrants, Frank is a Florida native and holds a B.A. in philosophy from Harvard University and an M.P.A. from the LBJ School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas. After graduation, he worked on Wall Street as a public sector financial analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, structuring over $1 billion in financial transactions, before pursuing his graduate degree.

As vice president, community impact, Ayana Gabriel Turner leads and drives achievement of the Foundation’s equity goals and impact across the Atlanta metro region. She seeks to inspire philanthropy that will increase the region’s equity as well as the economic and social mobility of its residents. Ayana joins the Foundation following seven years at The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation, where she led education initiatives for children from birth through high school. She also oversaw Blank’s work around social justice, including NFL and Atlanta Falcons initiatives, as well as management of a fund focused on support of veterans of the U.S. Armed Forces. She co-led the inaugural Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Council for the businesses and Foundation. Her background includes managing diversity and education strategy for Teach for America, teaching science within the Atlanta Public Schools system and an earlier career as a chemical engineer. Ayana also has extensive experience in community leadership in her Westside Atlanta neighborhood. Ayana graduated from Spelman College and the Georgia Institute of Technology with dual bachelor’s degrees in chemistry and chemical engineering.

Connecting passion with purpose – Elyse lives to ignite positive change for indelible impact. To demonstrate that mantra, she has collaborated with her colleagues to double assets and giving for Atlanta’s community foundation, put Emory on top-10 healthcare lists, built and sold a marketing communications firm and changed human behavior by introducing the internet to consumers during a decade at BellSouth. Well versed at advancing hope and philanthropy via storytelling, Elyse has transformed brands leading agency, corporate, foundation and nonprofits organizations. Through her authentic, walk-her-talk collaborations, she has inspired teams to produce game-changing, award-winning programs for BellSouth, Chiquita Banana, Disney-On-Ice, Emory University, Georgia’s Food Banks, and more. A graduate of Emory University, Elyse holds a Universal Accreditation in Public Relations (APR/2001); became a member of the Public Relations Society of America’s prestigious College of Fellows in 2022; and will be the 2023 State of Georgia’s PR Hall of Fame inductee in March of this year.

Elyse co-chairs the accreditation committee of the Public Relations Society of America’s board, after serving as the Georgia chapter’s 2017 president. She serves on the advisory boards of the Junior League of Atlanta, the national Community Foundation Awareness Initiative and The Communications Network, the last two being volunteer, life-long learning associations championing equity for CEOs and communicators serving neighbors and communities.

Novella Noble leads the Foundation’s human resources and people strategies. She fosters a rich team culture via coaching, employee engagement, performance management, recruitment, retention, succession planning and training.

She collaborates with her peer senior executives and frontline leaders to align HR and business strategy. Novella leverages over 20 years of HR experience from her tenures at JenCare Senior Medical Center, Ochsner Health System, Automatic Data Processing (ADP), Trammel Crow Company, and Experian.

Novella earned a Bachelor of Arts in Criminal Justice and an Executive MBA from Kennesaw State University. She also holds the Professional Human Resources (PHR) certification from the Society for Human Resources Management (SHRM).

She volunteers her time in underserved communities through job empowerment initiatives for teenage moms and single parents. She is also the co-founder of a nonprofit called Empowerment through Education and Economics, providing resources to deprived communities in Guyana, South America. Novella and her husband, Victor, Sr., have two adult sons, Victor Junior and Demarcus. Novella enjoys cooking, gardening, reading and traveling in her spare time.

Debbie Schumacher-Jones serves as Chief of Staff for the Foundation. In her role, she is responsible for representing the Office of the CEO internally and externally, facilitating the open and efficient flow of information with and from the Office of the CEO and ensuring the effective integration of strategic and operational priorities aligned with the CEO’s vision for the organization. Additionally, she manages the newly formed Administrative Department and its staff.

Prior to this role, Debbie served as Executive Assistant to the President and CEO, Frank Fernandez, with whom she has worked for the past seven years. She also continues to serve as liaison to the Community Foundation’s Board of Directors.

Prior to joining the Foundation, Debbie was a Program Specialist and Executive Assistant at The Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation.

Debbie, an ATLien and tortured Atlanta sports fan, graduated from Kennesaw State University with a bachelor’s degree in communication and media studies, which she completed while working full time. She and her husband Jason are raising their two young boys in SW Atlanta.

Mark Sutton joined the Foundation in 2022 as chief financial officer (CFO), responsible for leading all accounting, financial and investment divisions of the $1.4 billion regional endowment. Prior to joining the Foundation, Mark served as executive vice president and CFO at United Way World Wide for four years, leading financial operations, IT and merchandising/vendor relationships for more than 1,800 United Ways in 41 countries. He managed an investment portfolio of more than $40 million, as well as a diverse revenue portfolio consisting of donor-advised funds, corporate contributions, overseas transactions and private and government grants.

Mark knows the metro Atlanta region well, previously serving 17 years as Executive Vice President and CFO for United Way of Greater Atlanta, responsible for operating an annual budget of more than $100 million serving Atlanta and 13 surrounding counties. He managed all financial affairs, including the creation of a board designated operating reserve policy which went from $0 in revenue cash reserves to over $11 million in five years. He also led a Strategic Resource Development committee, a sub-committee of the Board of Directors focused on fundraising strategies, negotiated the employee benefits plan and managed a number of successful initiatives including the “iMatter” campaign for first-time donors and a “60 days to success” campaign which was focused on digital strategy.

Prior to his tenure at United Way, Atlanta, Mark was CFO for the Association of County Commissioners of Georgia for five years. He led the accounting functions, including managing $300 million assets for the organization’s workers compensation fund, pension fund and local risk management fund. He also developed and implemented the annual budget and coordinated year-end audits and insurance funds. Mark is a change management champion and Six Sigma Green Belt expert leading transformational changes and driving organizational efficiencies. He earned his Bachelor's degree in accounting from George Washington University and is a licensed Certified Public Accountant (CPA).

Liz Liston is responsible for planning and implementing the fund development strategy, focusing on deepening relationships with current donors. She has nearly 16 years of nonprofit experience and has focused her career on fundraising, marketing, donor relations, and major gift strategy. Liz has served the Atlanta community through fundraising positions with HOPE Atlanta, CHRIS 180, The Galloway School, and Truancy Intervention Project Georgia, and raised funds for the Fisher College of Business at The Ohio State University.

She most recently served as the Chief Development Officer at HOPE Atlanta, the city’s oldest homeless serving organization. There, she helped to build the agency’s philanthropic strategy to support programming for individuals and families experiencing homelessness and housing insecurity, which resulted in 400% growth over 3 years. Liz has dedicated most of her career to local Atlanta nonprofits that serve our community’s most vulnerable. She has supported missions specific to mental health, housing/homelessness, foster care, at-risk youth, and education. She enjoys interacting with donors to align their philanthropic interests with programs and services that build a thriving community for all. Liz is a native of Columbus, Ohio and holds an MPA in Nonprofit Management from the Andrew Young School of Policy Studies at Georgia State University and a BA in Psychology from Sewanee: The University of the South.

As Director, Philanthropic & General Counsel, Kevin Allen Nash is responsible for leading legal matters, ensuring compliance, managing risks and providing strategic guidance for the philanthropic team to support the Foundation's mission to lead our region toward equity and shared prosperity for all.

Prior to joining the Foundation, Kevin served as Associate General Counsel for Bethune-Cookman University. He has over a decade of legal practice experience and almost twenty years in the nonprofit sector. Kevin has long been committed to making a meaningful impact on communities through his volunteer work with at-risk youth and pro-bono legal services for underserved communities.

Kevin earned his Bachelor's in Political Science from Walsh University (North Canton, OH) and his Juris Doctorate from Florida A&M University College of Law. He holds his LL.M. in Labor and Employment Law. Kevin is a Past President of Virgil Hawkins Florida Chapter of the National Bar Association and currently serves as the Co-Chair for the Judicial Nominating Procedures Committee and serves on the Civil Procedures Rules Committee, Leadership Academy Committee, and Education Law Committee of the Florida Bar Association. Kevin and his wife Melissa have two adult children, Jason and Nicole. He enjoys reading, traveling and cycling in his spare time.

As director of donor engagement, Kimberly Spear leads relationship development with new donors and families at the Community Foundation, helping them to realize their philanthropic goals. Kim works with individuals and organizations that wish to open a philanthropic fund to collectively support the needs of the Atlanta region.

Before joining the Foundation, Kimberly held positions at higher education institutions and nonprofit organizations. Most recently, she served as the executive director of development at Clayton State University. Kimberly was responsible for generating unrestricted and designated support to meet annual financial goals through the solicitation of prospects within an assigned portfolio and she managed the President’s Advisory Board and the University’s Coca-Cola First-Generation Scholarship Program. Kimberly also worked at Habitat for Humanity as corporate sponsorship manager for one year and spent three years with Georgia State University as development director.

Kimberly is a graduate of Georgia Southern University in Statesboro, Georgia, with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Journalism. She is working towards her master's degree in Strategic Leadership Development at Clayton State. She is an active member of the Junior League of Atlanta. She serves on the capacity-building committee to help educate and train members to tackle issues such as generational poverty, education equality and human trafficking. She is also a graduate of the Atlanta Regional Commission’s Regional Leadership Institute and Leadership Clayton. Kimberly resides in the Southern Crescent with her husband and three children.

Shun Sayres supports several directors across the organization. She comes to the Foundation with over 12+ years of administrative experience in the healthcare industry. Before this role, Pashun served as Administrative Assistant and Interim Project Manager at the Morehouse School of Medicine, responsible for maintaining calendars, scheduling meetings, creating campaign dashboards, and controlling and managing document processes and critical information to confirm the accuracy of policies and procedures. Pashun provided administrative support to the Vice President of the Office of Institutional Advancement. She spent four years at the Emory University Hospital as Administrative Assistant and Access Coordinator. In that role, Pashun was responsible for maintaining confidential records, managing multiple high-functioning projects, checking in patients for surgery, handling large volumes of incoming calls, maintaining calendars, and scheduling meetings for; 4 Unit Directors and 3 Unit Managers. Pashun spent three years at the Southern Crescent Hospital as a Patient Care Technician/ Secretary.

Pashun graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Business with A Human Resource Management certification in 2021 from the University of Phoenix.

Her favorite quote is, “No one can make you feel inferior without your consent” ~ Eleanor Roosevelt.

Dr. Kristy Arnold serves as Director of Community Impact, where she is responsible for leading the emerging place-based strategy of the Foundation’s TogetherATL plan. Prior to joining the Foundation, Kristy served as Executive Director for LIFT-DC where she promoted LIFT’s anti-poverty mission, secured long-standing donor partnerships, and encouraged innovative programming for families in the Washington, DC area. Throughout her career, Kristy primarily served in community-based organizations developing programs and conducting groups centered around life/leadership empowerment, in addition to providing counseling services to families, couples, youth and young adults.

Dr. Arnold holds a B.S. in Psychology from the University of Georgia, M.Ed. from Howard University, and PhD in Counselor Education & Supervision from Virginia Tech. As a proud native Atlantan, Kristy is excited to support the leadership of the Community Foundation’s impact team as a dedicated broker of change with a strong belief in the goals of TogetherATL to bring various stakeholders together throughout the city.

Kristy currently resides in Decatur, Georgia, and is an active member of several organizations, with a special interest in volunteerism and mentoring youth & young adults. She also enjoys spending quality time with her family, friends, and sorority sisters discussing their plans to take over the world one pair of stilettos at a time.

Serving as a Program Officer, Conrhonda joins the Community Foundation to focus on its Arts, Culture and Creative Enterprises grantmaking portfolio. Conrhonda’s passion for the performing arts is grounded in her dance background, sparked by taking after-school classes at a county-wide recreational facility in rural northeast Georgia. Having grown up with school field trips to Atlanta to experience the arts, she understands the importance of exposing children to creative outlets and creating opportunities for artistic expression. She believes in holistic trust-based, regenerative, and restorative grant-making approaches.

Conrhonda developed her philanthropic, fundraising, government affairs, and program development experience through work with Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts, Alabama Dance Council, Vulcan Park and Museum, Birmingham Museum of Art, Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation, Howard Gilman Foundation, and South Arts. She has sat on grant panels for Cuyahoga Arts & Culture, Dance/NYC, the National Endowment for the Arts, NYC Department of Cultural Affairs, and the NY Community Trust. In addition to being a Women of Color in the Arts member, she serves on the Board of Directors for SOLE Defined and Arts Business Collaborative. She holds a Master of Arts Management from Carnegie Mellon University and a Bachelor of Arts in African American Studies with a minor in Dance Education from The University of Georgia.

Dominque serves as the Program Associate for Income and Wealth, as well as Arts, Culture, and Creative Enterprises. Her work helps support wealth-building and dismantling systems of wealth extraction that affect our communities. She also helps support Metro Atlanta’s arts and culture ecosystem. Earning her AAS in Environmental Horticulture, her BS in Environmental Studies from Unity College, and multiple certifications in various specialized environmental topics, Dominque brings a unique perspective to the Foundation. As an environmental specialist, she reflects the concept of sustainability in her analytical thinking.

Dominque’s work has perpetually been focused on community. Before joining the Foundation, she served as a Certified Horticulturist and Program Assistant in Agricultural and Natural Resources for the University of Georgia Extension Services, A Library Senior at the Clayton County Library System, an Environmental Consultant with Fresh Greens Market for the Clarke Street Fund, and a Program Associate for The Strategic Partnerships Team with Alternate ROOTS. She enjoys helping BIPOC artists and environmentalists seek out resources to help strengthen metropolitan communities. She has worked with individuals from all over the south, including Montgomery, Alabama, New Orleans, Louisiana, and Charleston, South Carolina.

In her spare time, Dominque is a dedicated tabletop gamer, reads graphic novels, and plays recreationally/volunteers with Atlanta Roller Derby.

Katrina Julien serves as Senior Program Officer, focused on the Foundation’s place-based portfolio. Katrina’s commitment to the Atlanta region aims to uplift and amplify resident voice in decision-making to advance social and economic mobility in their communities. Katrina provides vision and leadership that support the preservation and development of affordable housing, uplifts community centered economic development, and promotes safe and inclusive neighborhoods as a right for all metro Atlanta communities. Her role within community supports the Foundation’s mission of increasing equity and shared prosperity throughout the region.

Before joining the Foundation, Katrina worked as Principal Program Specialist in the Community Partnerships Division at the Atlanta Regional Commission. There, she was responsible for the planning and implementation of the Community Partnerships division’s leadership development programs and the coordination of the agency’s Poverty, Equity Opportunity (PEO) Committee where the ARC facilitated conversations around poverty and economic inclusion for all residents in the Atlanta region.

Katrina earned a Bachelor of Science in Psychology from Georgia State University and her Master’s in Public Administration from Walden University.

Jovan Paige leads strategies for Power and Leadership in the Community Impact Team. Before joining us, Jovan served as Donor Relations and Communications Specialist at Ron Clarke Academy for two years, being responsible for the following: maintaining an accurate donor database through fundraising software, Raiser’s Edge; managing and responding to inquiries from the executive leadership of foundations and companies; operating as social media manager for the school’s social media platforms; and cultivating marketing strategies for email communications while ensuring the updating of content on the official RCA website and other social mediums including Twitter, TikTok and LinkedIn.

Jovan also served as the Director of Millennial, Youth, and College Engagement for the 2018 Stacey Abrams for Governor Campaign, making him the youngest statewide director in Georgia. He was tasked with identifying, creating, and managing events targeting the millennial, college, and youth constituencies in all 12 regions of Georgia, empowering the Millennial Voters to take control of their destiny by using their voice. With a passion for empowering youth and millennials to take control of their destiny, Jovan founded Stay Jotivated LLC in January of 2017, a motivational speaking, event hosting, and empowerment brand focused on the pursuit of passions and the conquering of obstacles that stand in the way of the realization of dreams. Jovan has spoken at nearly 200 events ranging from K-12, College & University events, corporate engagements, graduations, rallies, and induction ceremonies. Jovan remains active in the community by being a champion of philanthropy in Atlanta, named to the Young Nonprofit Professional Network (YNPN) 30 under 30 in 2022 and honored as the Kevin A. Gooch Emerging Leader of the Year in 2019 and 2021 with the Emerging 100 of Atlanta. Jovan graduated with a Bachelor's degree in Public Policy from Georgia State University in 2016.

Lauren Thomas Priest (she/her/hers) serves as a program officer on the Community Impact Team. She leads strategies to reduce racial income and wealth gaps in metro Atlanta through the Foundation’s Income & Wealth systems work.

Originally from Cleveland, Ohio, Lauren has lived in the Atlanta area with her three children for more than five years. She has twelve years of experience working within the nonprofit sector, including roles in development, direct service, outreach, and program management, and joined the Foundation because of its focus on making our region more equitable for all of its residents.

She earned a Bachelor of Arts in International Studies from Miami University of Ohio, and a Master of Nonprofit Management from Regis University. Lauren was awarded a Northeast Ohio Top 25 Under 35 Movers and Shakers Award from The Cleveland Professional 20/30 Club and a 30 Under 30 Nonprofit Leader Award from the Atlanta chapter of the Young Nonprofit Professional Network.

Kaela Hammond is passionate about connecting communities, nonprofits, and donors to work together to improve our local community, particularly in the area of affordable housing. In her role as Program Officer she manages a housing policy and programs grants portfolio aligned to the Foundation’s TogetherATL Housing strategy. Kaela is thrilled to be a member of the 2023-2024 Hull Fellows class through Philanthropy Southeast, developing her leadership skills as part of the greater philanthropic community.

Kaela comes to the Foundation from Charleston, SC, where she spent nearly eight years at the Coastal Community Foundation, most recently as a Program Officer. Prior to that, she spent several years teaching in Title I elementary schools in Greensboro, NC and North Charleston, SC.

Kaela is originally from Spartanburg, SC, and earned a degree in Elementary Education, with a minor in Spanish, from Wake Forest University. She is excited to explore Atlanta with her husband, two dogs, and cat. In her free time, she loves to hike and run, read any fiction she can get her hands on, and explore new places.

Sarah Kirsch manages the affordable housing investment portfolios for the Foundation, both social impact and philanthropic funds, as a key pillar for advancing equitable growth in our region. In support of TogetherATL’s neighborhood and housing goals, the funds are designed to provide gap funding and support deeper and longer-term affordability for rental and ownership homes. Prior to joining the Foundation, Sarah spent ten years with the Urban Land Institute (ULI) and served as Executive Director of the Atlanta District Council. Her work at ULI focused on advancing inclusive walkable urban places with a specific focus on housing affordability and the connections between transportation and land use. Prior to ULI, she spend 12 years with Robert Charles Lesser & Co. (RCLCO), the nation’s leading independent real estate advisory firm.

Sarah’s civic leadership is deeply rooted in housing affordability and community development, serving on the HouseATL board, as vice-chair of the Board of Commissioners for Atlanta Housing, on the Atlanta Urban Development Corporation board, and Neighborhood Empowerment subcommittee chair for Mayor Dickens’ transition team. Kirsch is a native of Atlanta and continues to live in the city where she and her husband are raising their three sons. Most weekends you will find her at track meets and cross-country events supporting her boys. She earned her Bachelor of Arts in Public Policy from Duke University’s Terry Sanford School of Public Policy.

Kayla Jones was born and raised in Brooklyn, New York. She received a Bachelor of Science in Education and Social Policy from Northwestern University. She also has her Master of Divinity and Master of Business Administration from Emory University’s Candler School of Theology and Goizueta Business School. Kayla began working at the Foundation as a Social Impact Fellow supporting the Georgia Social Impact Collaborative (GSIC) and GoATL Fund. Kayla transitioned to the GoATL Economic Inclusion Fund Manager (GEI Fund) role after completing the fellowship. The GEI Fund aims to provide capital to Black, women and other underinvested small business owners who routinely struggle to access the capital needed to grow and scale their businesses. This new fund aligns with the Foundation’s strategic plan to make this region more equitable and prosperous for all, specifically by creating wealth and employment opportunities for ATL residents.

Before coming to the Foundation, Kayla worked as the Communications Specialist at the Impact Movement and the FAO Schwarz Fellow at Jumpstart for Young Children. Kayla loves traveling, reading, writing, photography, roller skating and exploring good restaurants in her spare time.

As controller, Andrea is responsible for overseeing and leading all finance and accounting operations. Andrea has more than 25 years of accounting experience in nonprofit, financial services, public accounting, and the management of accounting operations and financial reporting. Before joining the Foundation, Andrea served in various roles at the Rockefeller Brothers Fund for 14 years. Most recently, Andrea served as Director of Accounting at the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) and Treasurer of the Rockefeller Family Fund (RFF) in New York where she led the accounting department operations of RBF and RFF and managed the financial and investment reporting in her capacity as Treasurer of RFF.

Andrea has managed, trained, and mentored accounting staff and recruited several temporary staff. Her extensive knowledge spans the functional areas including profit and loss oversight, budgeting and forecasting, audit, tax, internal controls and more.

Andrea earned her Bachelor of Science degree in Accounting & Business Administration at the University of Belize. She and her husband relocated from New York in November 2020 and reside northeast of Atlanta, close to their families. In her spare time, Andrea enjoys traveling, trying different restaurants and watching movies and documentaries.
